sentence.text: ` In its search to reveal secrets of human existence , " it trumpeted , ` science has brought us undoubted gifts .
The admen trumpeted : ` Ever heard the Algerian national anthem ?
` But the responsibility is yours , " the Doctor trumpeted .
` If it was suicide , " he trumpeted , ` it 's a damn " strange way to go .
Now my clerk and I , " he trumpeted , ` would like to question each of you alone .
` The son of a bitch ought to be impeached , " trumpeted McCarthy .
A writer in the Town Planning Review trumpeted that train-sheds were now obsolete : ` modern terminals in great cities must be below street level hereafter " .
People who trumpet the dangers of strict capital rules also exaggerate the benefits that leniency would bring .
Embarrassingly for Mr Ben Ali , who likes to trumpet the virtues of Tunisian democracy , all the seats went to his own RCD party .

THE potential export value to Britain of an indigenous pressurised water reactor ( PWR ) programme was trumpeted by the National Nuclear Corporation this week as the Sizewell inquiry adjourned for its Easter break .
SIX years ago , in the introduction to a collection of his plays , Howard Brenton was still trumpeting his adherence to Marxism and looking forward to an unstoppable ` British Revolution " .
She knew at last why Spittals had been so keen to trumpet the arrest of John Hebden and she was not happy about it .
The Government trumpet the £140 reduction , but the reduction given to those on income support is inadequate and does not match the needs of those in receipt of that money .
Today , the barge docks in Kuala Lumpar where Sir Peter Carey , chairman of Morgan Grenfell , will trumpet the merits of the City on behalf of the British Invisible Exports Council .
When next they start going up month by month , will the headlines trumpet , Good news for home owners ?
